stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a mission in Course 11 where the player must disrupt five groups of Bowser's workers. The stream covers implementing a domino-style Whomp tower based on a viewer's idea, debugging an N64 hardware-specific crash, programming NPC interactions for a cement-mixing Koopa, and refining the level layout, all while collaborating with animator Zeina and discussing composer Badub's progress.

development_findings.summary: The game is being optimized for ROM size by reducing the file size of sound effects, which frees up space for streamed audio tracks (WAV files) that are less performance-intensive than sequenced music in large areas.
development_findings.quote: The smaller the ROM is, the more space we're gonna for mp3 files... and every time we use a WAV file instead of a song we save a lot of performance in that level.

development_findings.summary: A key level set-piece, a tower of Whomps that fall like dominoes, was created based on a spontaneous suggestion from a viewer in the chat.
development_findings.quote: That is such a funny idea... that's actually one of the benefits of streaming. Sometimes that one is just a really funny idea.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against obvious player guidance (like exclamation marks), preferring multiple, subtle, layered hints that allow the player to feel smart for discovering the solution.
development_findings.quote: It's like admitting oh, I can't make a good game. Let me just make sure the player knows how it works anyway... it's like the principle of show. Don't tell.

development_findings.summary: To motivate players to disrupt the level's worker NPCs, they are being written with rude and antagonistic dialogue towards Mario.
development_findings.quote: Make the workers root to Mario so players want to fuck them up. I like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's philosophy on difficulty is that it should be a natural outcome of creating interesting and cool platforming challenges, rather than being a goal in and of itself.
development_findings.quote: I actually believe that difficulty in a game is not a thing you should strive for. Instead you should strive for having cool platforming and sometimes the cool platforming just so will happen to require something more difficult to do.

development_findings.summary: A game crash occurring only on real N64 hardware was traced to a floating-point exception in the background rendering code, highlighting the importance of testing on original hardware.
The lighting system was modified to include a global brightness modifier, allowing for easier adjustments to level visibility after early feedback indicated levels were too dark.
development_findings.quote: I think it just looks way better in this game. It was way too dark before.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to significantly shorten a large platforming section of the level during the stream because it served no gameplay purpose and was a candidate for performance optimization.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that due to years of reverse engineering, the homebrew community now understands the N64's architecture better than its original creators.
context_findings.quote: I definitely know a lot more about the n64 to Nintendo ever did. It's not even that difficult to do because you know, it's been a long while.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels that avoiding discussing personal views or politics is a manipulative act to curate an audience, which he considers disingenuous.
context_findings.quote: Refusing to talk politics is very incriminating. I don't know. It's not incriminating, but it's like trying to hide yourself from the people that might dislike you for your views or something. It's such a psychopath thing to do.

context_findings.summary: Kaze notes that his professional work as an Unreal Engine developer has ingrained coding habits, like excessive null pointer checks, that he finds unnecessary for this project.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I almost put in a null pointer check here. Working in professional game development fucked up my brain.

context_findings.summary: He streams on YouTube instead of Twitch because he couldn't stand the number of ads on Twitch.
Kaze mentions that his area was experiencing a record-breaking thunderstorm and significant flooding at the time of the stream.

badub.summary: Badub, the composer, has returned to the project after a period of absence.
badub.quote: Dude but dude finally wrote me again today. He's back and he's making music again.

badub.summary: He is struggling to create a suitable track for the current level, having made ten unsuccessful attempts, but Kaze praises his dedication.
badub.quote: He said he's been working on it for a week and he said like 10 different tries and he just can't figure out how to make a good one. But he's really putting in the effort, which is really really good for us.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the idle and falling animations for the Whomp models, including variations for those in the middle of the chain reaction versus the end.
She provides direct artistic feedback during the stream, prompting Kaze to change the eyes on a Koopa model to look more annoyed.
zeina.quote: Please change his eyes, he looks so weird. I can't draw eyes. You do it.

zeina.summary: She created multiple animations for the Koopa worker, including talking and angry states, which were implemented during the stream.
She is working on a personal 3D modeling project of a 'banana cat' in her spare time, which Kaze showed off on stream.

key_stories.title: The Whomp Tower
key_stories.summary: A central level set-piece, the Whomp tower, was conceived and developed live on stream. The initial problem of what to do with a group of Whomps was solved by a viewer's suggestion, which Kaze immediately embraced and built upon with modeling, animation from Zeina, and physics programming.
key_stories.challenge: The level featured a group of Whomp models, but their purpose and gameplay function were undecided.
key_stories.process: A viewer suggested the Whomps could form a tower that falls like dominoes. Kaze embraced the idea, modeled a basic tower, received falling animations from Zeina, programmed the chain reaction physics, and added particle effects for impact.
key_stories.outcome: A unique and comedic interactive set-piece was created for the level, demonstrating a collaborative and improvisational development process that incorporates live community feedback.
key_stories.key_quote: You have all the funny ideas tonight. Hey, that's actually one of the benefits of streaming. Sometimes that one is just a really funny idea.

key_stories.title: Player Guidance Philosophy
key_stories.summary: Kaze debated how to guide players to complete a mission requiring five separate interactions. He rejected obvious UI hints in favor of a layered, subtle approach, drawing on past experience and establishing a core design principle for the game.
key_stories.challenge: How to make players understand they need to disrupt five specific groups of workers without explicitly telling them with an intrusive UI element like an exclamation mark.
key_stories.process: Kaze rejected obvious hints, calling them a 'cheap copout.' He decided to use multiple, subtle layers: an overseer NPC who gives hints, making the worker NPCs rude to Mario to encourage interaction, and designing the interactions to be inherently inviting to disrupt.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design philosophy of 'show, don't tell' was established for the mission. The goal is to make players feel smart for discovering the solution themselves through one of several available clues, rather than being explicitly told what to do.
key_stories.key_quote: I want as many hints as possible, as many layers of you know safety as possible. But I want not a single hint to be like overbearing.

key_stories.title: The N64 Hardware Crash
key_stories.summary: The game crashed on real N64 hardware, but not on an emulator, prompting a live debugging session. Kaze delved into the assembly code to diagnose the problem, showcasing his deep technical knowledge of the console.
key_stories.challenge: A level that worked perfectly on an emulator crashed with a floating-point exception when tested on a real N64 console.
key_stories.process: Kaze ran a debug version on the console to find the crash address. He then examined the assembly code, identified the function responsible for rendering the background, and deduced the crash was related to an issue when reading data from a color table.
key_stories.outcome: The specific function causing the crash was identified, demonstrating the necessity of testing on original hardware to catch platform-specific bugs. The fix was postponed to continue with the stream's planned content.
key_stories.key_quote: So there is a crash in this function here on n64 only. Should be pretty easy to fix.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that composer Badub is back but struggling with the music for the current level, having made 10 different attempts over a week.

open_questions.context: Kaze and Zeina collaborated live on animations. Kaze would make a modeling change, send it to Zeina, who would then create and send back animations, sometimes providing artistic feedback.
questions: Can you walk us through your typical workflow when Kaze needs a new animation for a character?

open_questions.context: Kaze confirmed that multiplayer is still planned and briefly mentioned the design problem of a playable character who is also an NPC in the world (e.g., Waluigi).
